Title: Cowboy Carter
Description: The follow-up to Renaissance is a powerful and ambitious country album cast in the singular mold of Beyoncé. She asserts her rightful place in the genre as only a pop star of her incredible talent and influence can do.

Title: Psykos
Description: The Swedish savants team up for their first collaborative project, a sincere commitment to alt-rock and post-punk that brings the genres’ darkness into a new era.

Title: Forest Scenes
Description: Working with cello, digital processing, and field recordings, the New York composer creates a gripping ode to the dynamism of nature and the beauty of transformation.

Title: Modus Operandi
Description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit Photek’s 1997 debut, a breathtaking, transcendent drum’n’bass album that changed the language and landscape of the genre.

Title: funk​.​BR - S​ã​o Paulo
Description: NTS’ latest compilation is a brain-frying rollercoaster of club maximalism, showcasing the funk paulista underworld’s endless creativity.

Title: Moves in the Field
Description: Working with the Yamaha Disklavier—a digital descendant of the player piano—the New York musician explores the tension between technical precision and emotional reverie.

Title: Catching Chickens EP
Description: On the follow-up to last year’s Erotic Probiotic 2, the Baltimore musician continues to twist the sounds of ’80s dream pop and R&B into a strange, heartfelt picture of a world on the brink.

Title: Fire Escape
Description: The startlingly accomplished solo debut from the art-pop singer-songwriter is a world of birdsong, whistles, hums, and silence, anchored by her magnetic voice.

Title: Ten Total
Description: On his chic, adventurous, hybrid-pop debut, Benjamin Lyman is a world-weary optimist and DIY maximalist with a voice fit for the mainstream yet made for the arthouse

Title: Akoma
Description: On her dazzlingly detailed new album of experimental post-footwork, the Indiana producer pushes extreme rhythmic precision so far that it begins to feel psychedelic.

Title: It’s Over
Description: The London singer and producer’s glamorous, infernally catchy new dance-pop record suffers from a deeply modern affliction.

Title: WE DON’T TRUST YOU
Description: Two of rap’s biggest hitmakers team up for a sleek, vengeful project that somewhat successfully tries to recapture the feeling of an event album.

Title: Tyla
Description: The South African singer’s star-making debut is a lithe, contemporary take on pop-R&B that pulses with the log-drum heartbeat of amapiano.

Title: Bite Down
Description: Working again with members of David Nance & Mowed Sound, the North Carolina singer-songwriter finds an easy, patient groove pitched between Americana and classic rock.

Title: For Your Consideration
Description: Lorely Rodriguez’s fourth album is a dazzling showcase for her unexpected vocal and production approach as she experiences the peaks and valleys of heated romance.

Title: Real Power
Description: Beth Ditto’s second solo LP turned into a full-fledged Gossip comeback once her bandmates got involved. Rick Rubin captures the carefree vibes of old friends enjoying each other’s company.

Title: Truest
Description: Foregrounding her voice for the first time against airy, otherworldly beats, the Brooklyn producer’s new tape is her most lucid and surprising to date.

Title: Something in the Room She Moves
Description: Turning toward improvisation and meditative minimalism, the Los Angeles singer and songwriter’s latest album seeks a release from rational thought. It sounds fluid, sonorous, and free.

Title: Black Sheep
Description: The New York rapper’s third studio album is an unbothered mission statement that displays his gifts as a bar-for-bar rapper and thrilling genre collagist.

Title: The Messthetics and James Brandon Lewis
Description: This meeting of punk and jazz heavyweights sidesteps contemporary trends; instead we’re treated to four players finding common ground as they slip between genres.

Title: Meat Puppets II
Description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit the Meat Puppets’ 1984 album, a sun-baked, country-fried, acid-addled cowpunk album that could have come from nowhere else but the Arizona desert.

Title: The Carnegie Hall Concert
Description: This newly issued 1971 set helpfully complicates the iconic harpist and pianist’s legacy, revealing her as not just a spiritual-jazz mystic but also the heir to her late husband’s harshly ecstatic fire music.

Title: Tigers Blood
Description: Carrying forth the Southern sound of Saint Cloud, Katie Crutchfield does it again. Her dazzling, piercing songwriting is perfectly in tune with the band behind her.

Title: Glasgow Eyes
Description: The Scottish noise-pop legends’ second album since reuniting strikes a reflective, unusually congenial tone, paying tribute to rock history and their place within it.

Title: LVL5 P2
Description: The Atlanta rapper’s latest imagines a higher dimension where outré flexes and endless love affairs are enveloped by waves of metallic crunch and mind-expanding guitar.

Title: Bright Future
Description: Recorded straight to tape with a small group of close confidants, the Big Thief singer’s latest solo album is free-flowing and intuitive, reveling in the space between spontaneity and impermanence.

Title: Painting With John (Music From the Original TV Series)
Description: These whimsical, at times absurdist songs from the former Lounge Lizard’s gently quixotic HBO series seem designed to channel the beautiful weirdness at the heart of the human experience.

Title: Princ​€​ss
Description: This shadowy collective’s debut album is as nebulous as its members’ identities. An amorphous mixture of guitars, electronics, and wispy vocals, it mimics the blurriness of a dream.

Title: Blue Angeles
Description: The Massachusetts-raised singer-songwriter’s second album exudes a quiet intensity, slipping between gentle indie rock and barely-there folk songs with bottomless vulnerability.

Title: Everything I Thought It Was
Description: The pop star’s latest is less of a faceplant than a comfortable rehash of past glories. He scales his stuttering electro and squelchy ’80s funk into hollow, expensive-sounding maximalism.

Title: Deep Sage
Description: Back from pandemic-induced hiatus, the Florida-based band fuses urgent post-hardcore with softer strains of shoegaze and grunge to unlock a new power of restraint.

Title: The ADDENDUM - i was mature for my age, but i was still a child
Description: On the deluxe version of its debut full-length, the trio struggles to find a middle ground between treacly verses and the bubbly pop-rap they’re known for.

Title: Fine Ho, Stay
Description: Capping off the Ho trilogy, Flo Milli flexes and shines on some of her best songs yet, even if the album is a little uneven.

Title: Come With Me If You Want to Live
Description: Despite its jacked-up end-times framing, the former Majical Cloudz singer’s third solo album mostly hews to the melancholy synth pop and emotional interrogations of his previous solo work.

Title: Mr Beat the Road
Description: The “Get in With Me” rapper’s single-minded focus on getting money and spending it irresponsibly is a perfect distraction from the precarity of real life.

Title: World Wide Whack
Description: Five years after her brief but spectacular debut, Tierra Whack digs deep into her psyche for an anxious, dark, and raw follow-up. She remains a magnetic performer even if the music has lost some of its color.

Title: Pinball
Description: Continuing his impressive run, MIKE links with the Brooklyn producer for a deliriously fun record of low-stakes raps and bubbly beats. It’s the most energetic project the rapper’s ever made, an unexpected but welcome vibe change.

Title: The World of Harry Partch
Description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit the 1969 album that provided a pioneering experimental composer with his own scales and instruments to make music that elevated stories from the fringes of American life to mythological status.

Title: Power to the People
Description: The virtuoso saxophonist’s 1969 album with Herbie Hancock, Ron Carter, and Jack DeJohnette is an essential document of a transitional moment in which everything in jazz seemed up for grabs.

Title: Three
Description: Kieren Hebden has been letting loose on stage, but he keeps it restrained on his smartly sequenced album that deftly incorporates virtually every style of music that he’s made over the years.

Title: Unleash
Description: The Chicago footwork producer trades the genre’s emphasis on sampling for ultra-vivid sound design fleshed out with futuristic textures and classic synths.

Title: Deeper Well
Description: The country star’s sixth album is an endlessly pretty back-to-basics record focused on growing and bettering oneself. It’s a balm, even if her sharp songwriting has dulled a bit.

Title: The Great Bailout
Description: Fueled by controlled fury and unfathomable sorrow, Camae Ayewa’s latest album of Afrofuturist collage traces the traumatic legacy of European colonialism.

Title: Where’s My Utopia?
Description: On their second album, the UK post-punks embrace a more playful, dynamic sound, while acerbic frontman James Smith trades caricature for self-reflection.

Title: Queen of the Land
Description: Fueled by off-the-cuff bars, absurdist maximalism, and elastic flows, the artist’s new mixtape is a welcome blast of rowdy Atlanta rap.

Title: Y’Y
Description: The Brazilian pianist brings his dazzling polyrhythms—plus guests like Jeff Parker and Brandee Younger—to an album that fuses jazz, avant-garde composition, and indigenous Amazonian influences.

Title: Flora Ocean Tiger Bloom
Description: Chad Ubovich returns from the brink with a dark, ambitious psych-rock record. The fuzz-drone riffs are big enough to hit the rafters and there’s plenty of niche touches for the heads.

Title: eternal sunshine
Description: The pop star returns with a restrained, slightly scattered, but emotionally generous album that cycles through the collapse of one relationship and into the hopeful beginning of another.

Title: Querid​ã​o
Description: The Belo Horizonte-based producer has developed an eerie, minimalist take on Brazilian funk that’s a world away from the heavier strains associated with Río de Janeiro or São Paulo.

Title: It’s About Time
Description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit SWV’s 1992 prodigious debut, a stylish album that added a singular realness to the sound of R&B.

Title: Letter to Yu
Description: Following his 2022 collaboration with Charlotte Adigéry, the Belgian-born producer examines his Hong Kong heritage on an album of clean-lined synth pop and invigorating club tracks.

Title: The Collective
Description: Pairing blown-out trap beats and industrial noise with deadpan stream-of-consciousness lyrics, Gordon’s second solo album revels in the broken and the mundane.

Title: Bleachers
Description: On his fourth solo album, Jack Antonoff and his band keep writing their own version of the rock’n’roll myth. It’s clever, empathetic, and still a bit clunky.

Title: Keeper of the Shepherd
Description: With the energy and conviction of a debut, the intuitive singer-songwriter returns with a dazzling folk album that contends with the long grip of grief and the belief that it will steadily loosen.

Title: Playing Favorites
Description: The Philadelphia rockers sign to Third Man, try a few new tricks, and kick out the jams with some diminishing returns.

Title: Lived and Born
Description: The California producer and New York rapper collaborate on a contemplative and captivating lo-fi rap record about moving through this life and into the next.

Title: Half Divorced
Description: The hardcore band’s sixth album is short, fast, and misanthropically funny, full of scuzz-punk tantrums about the indignities of modern life.

Title: Southside Sopranos
Description: The rapper’s new mixtape is a jewel of DC street rap, recounting hood epics and hustler origin stories with a potent sense of realism.

Title: Body of Work
Description: The veteran singer-songwriter made his name penning songs for other people. The classic rock and adult contemporary of his first album of original material in 18 years sound slick yet curiously anonymous.

Title: Scope Neglect
Description: The Australian noise musician has long used the guitar as a textural element, but here he puts it front and center, sculpting a claustrophobic landscape out of chugging metal riffs.

Title: Lip Flip EP
Description: After a 2021 debut that used deconstructed club music as an autobiographical frame, the London-based producer’s rhythmically focused new EP feels less revealing—but just as disorienting.

Title: Blue Lips
Description: The TDE rapper’s sixth album is a daring feat that finds the sweet spot between comfort and anguish. It’s the rawest and most adventurous music of his career.

Title: Untame the Tiger
Description: The guitar icon’s first solo album in 19 years confronts heartbreak and loss with intensely melodic, disarmingly straightforward songs that feel as loose and casual as old friends.

Title: Przygody
Description: With playful marimbas and chintzy MIDI instruments, the Polish ambient experimentalist’s tribute to urban exploration sits somewhere between reality and reimagining.

Title: New Miserable Experience
Description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit the ’90s alt-rock band’s debut, a tender and sincere record that made the band famous while they grappled with tragedy.

Title: All Life Long
Description: On an interconnected suite of pieces for pipe organ, brass ensemble, and chamber choir, the composer balances minimalist intensity with sacred music’s depth of feeling.

Title: Underdressed at the Symphony
Description: The Atlanta singer-songwriter’s latest record taps into freewheeling acoustic jam-session vibes. It’s ostensibly a breakup album, but rather than spilling her guts, she sounds more reserved than ever.

Title: Quiet Logic
Description: The 1998 collaborative album brought together a trio of legends from the worlds of ambient and chillout. It’s a placid but playful collection that is like nothing else in their repertoires.

Title: Antiposition
Description: Two veteran electronic producers balance their club instincts with headier inclinations, fusing breakbeats, dub delay, and squalling electronic frequencies into side-winding psychedelic excursions.

Title: I Got Heaven
Description: The Philadelphia rock band meets the moment with an essential, wide-ranging record that’s mouthy, messy, and self-assured.

Title: Souvenirs
Description: A remarkable archival release captures rare vocal performances that the esteemed nun, composer, and pianist recorded in the late 1970s and early ’80s amid political turmoil in Ethiopia.

Title: The Anchorite
Description: On the latest album from his ambient alter ego, Baths’ Will Wiesenfeld uses fuzzed-out guitars and tape-warped textures to conjure a blissful sense of refuge.

Title: Daniel
Description: The indie pop veterans’ sixth album fuses the laid-back sound of 1990s soft rock with pedal steel and countrypolitan filigree. It’s lean, clean—and a little sleepy.

Title: LAFANDAR
Description: The Queens-born, Punjabi-American rapper revels in the hyper-referential code-switching of his work in Das Racist and Swet Shop Boys while bringing newfound focus to his writing.

Title: The Past Is Still Alive
Description: Alynda Segarra’s fantastic new album revives the folky textures of previous records to grapple with American myths and tragedies. It’s part folk-punk memoir, part spiritual invocation.
The breakout rapper’s dystopian sci-fi concept album is full of glitzy soundscapes, rapidly morphing tempos, and naked cyborgian wails. Don’t mistake interstellar style for substance.

Title: Still
Description: Embracing the Y2K R&B of her youth, Erika de Casier molds the silvery avant-gardism of artists like Aaliyah and Janet Jackson into an ultra-stylish throwback for the era of ASMR.

Title: Contezza
Description: Pairing multilingual processed vocals with shape-shifting electroacoustic arrangements, the Italo-Congolese singer and composer explores the limits of the unconscious.

Title: Spectral Evolution
Description: After many years spent experimenting with arcane, home-built electronic devices, the Portuguese musician returns to his guitar for a gorgeous ambient suite informed by drone music and vintage jazz.

Title: Science Fiction
Description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit the great jazz saxophonist Ornette Coleman’s 1972 opus, a one-of-a-kind dispatch from the vibrant, polygenic, and contested lofts of downtown New York.

Title: Rooting for Love
Description: On her fifth solo album, the Stereolab principal highlights the contradictions at the heart of her music, pairing deceptively sweet arrangements with unsparing socio-political critique.

Title: Loss of Life
Description: After a 2018 album hailed as a return to form, the duo shifts to slick, big-tent pop pastiche—Britpop, power ballads, ’80s excess—delivered with arched brows and palpable yearning.

Title: On the Lips
Description: Guided by her spellbinding whistling, the Los Angeles musician’s debut album is as sumptuous and wistful as a vintage film score.

Title: Mother Engine
Description: The New York duo’s gloomy trip rock songs are danceable, depressing, and designed for you to mosh with your shadows.

Title: Blu Wav
Description: Inspired by waltz time, heartbreak, and ambient Americana, Jason Lytle returns with his characteristic mix of humor and tragedy.

Title: This Is Me…Now
Description: With throwback beats and baroque pop embellishments, J. Lo’s first solo album in 10 years chronicles a real-life fairy tale that threatens to overpower the music.

Title: Any Light
Description: Two tree planters ventured into the forest and emerged as a folk-pop duo. Inspired by ’70s radio and Jungian philosophy, their new album is a breezy meditation on spirit and belonging.

Title: Adult Contemporary
Description: The disco-funk duo’s grown and sexy album sounds like a glossy recreation of an established style—minus some of the idiosyncrasy and fun.

Title: back then I didn’t but now I do
Description: The Miami producer’s debut morphs between ambient, downtempo, and dub techno. It’s as tranquil as an afternoon spent watching the clouds drift through the sky.

Title: GRIP
Description: The Los Angeles-based singer and producer trades the gospel of his previous work for sensual R&B, using the club as his canvas for tender odes to queer desire.

Title: Hole in My Head
Description: With a solo album of playfully retro punk songs, the Against Me! singer lets her hair down but never loses sight of the stakes.

Title: Drop 7 EP
Description: The UK rapper celebrates her wins and flexes her Portuguese on an EP that pulses and jumps with a funky digital spark.

Title: The Emancipation of Mimi
Description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit Mariah Carey’s triumphant comeback, an album that captured the zeitgeist of 2000s R&B and resurrected a pop icon.

Title: Where we’ve been, Where we go from here
Description: Channeling the sound and spirit of 2000s indie rock, the Chicago duo’s debut album feels like a generational passing of the torch.

Title: TANGK
Description: On their fifth album, the UK band enlist Nigel Godrich and Kenny Beats for a smoother, softer rock record that still fires its love songs from a cannon.

Title: Imitation of War
Description: With layered guitars, drifting arrangements, and gently ambiguous songwriting, Kayla Cohen and her band invoke dream worlds and trance states.

Title: Two Star & the Dream Police
Description: Mike Gordon’s debut album warps ’80s pop, rock, and R&B with idiosyncratic production, yielding strange, murky songs full of anxiety and longing.

Title: VULTURES 1
Description: Kanye teams with Ty Dolla $ign for a project that actually sounds finished, but hardly puts anything worth remembering onto it.

Title: Harm’s Way
Description: The Toronto jangle-pop duo doesn’t attempt to upset the winning formula established on its 2021 debut; it just executes the same bittersweet moves with even more militaristic precision.

Title: Vida
Description: The Chilean rapper and singer’s unbreakable optimism and political conviction power an album animated by fresh explorations of pop ballads, reggaeton, and Afrobeats.

Title: Coming Home
Description: Usher’s ninth album is another impressive display of his endless charm and vocal chops. Thirty years into his career, the R&B icon still knows how to keep it light and throw a great party.

Title: RAVE:N, the Remixes
Description: Kelela’s latest collection of remixes is an adventurous victory lap, plunging deeper into her world of aqueous R&B.

Title: Walls Have Ears
Description: This storied 1986 live bootleg captured the band on the cusp between New York Noise act and alt-rock behemoth. Thirty-eight years later, it finally gets an official release.

Title: What Now
Description: The second solo album from the Alabama Shakes singer-songwriter is musically muscular and thematically heady, a sound nerd’s project with stadium-sized panache.

Title: The Closest Thing to Silence
Description: Based on improvisation and collage, the trio’s excellent debut incorporates strands of new age, ambient, electronic, and jazz for an illusory, hypnotic experience.

Title: Club Shy EP
Description: The British singer and producer delivers a satisfying little blast of club-pop bangers, channeling the big-room bliss of mid-’00s dance hits.

Title: Forgot About Me
Description: Slutever’s Rachel Gagliardi revs up big, glittery power-pop hooks for an album devoted to getting out of your own head and staying young at heart.

Title: Weird Faith
Description: After touring with Harry Styles, the Nashville songwriter returns with another showcase for her clear, expressive voice and exquisite sense of melody.

Title: Allina EP
Description: The Norwegian duo’s new EP chronicles the rise of a fictional 2000s pop star. It’s got all the glitz and glamour of that era, plus a little art-pop edge.

Title: Yerself Is Steam
Description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit Mercury Rev’s 1991 debut, a heroic dose of psychedelic rock that is equal parts nerve-wracking and awe-inspiring.

Title: David Nance & Mowed Sound
Description: On his debut for Third Man, the prolific Nebraska rocker tames his wild side but still lands some magnetic songs.

Title: Phasor
Description: Roberto Carlos Lange eases back into the groove with a gorgeous, delicately rendered album. It’s got space-age synths, wistful romance, and the breeziest vibe in town.

Title: El León
Description: Two dyed-in-the-wool New Yorkers unite for a sharp, mellow, and only a little greasy slice of hip-hop.

Title: She Reaches Out to She Reaches Out to She
Description: Assisted by producer Dave Sitek, the goth-folk shapeshifter explores a new dimension of her sound, bringing electronic atmospheres and industrial menace to an album about submitting to the unknown.

Title: Band on the Run (50th Anniversary Edition)
Description: Celebrating its 50th anniversary, a new expanded edition revisits the album that burnished McCartney’s critical reputation after the Beatles’ breakup, reestablishing as a force to contend with.

Title: Prelude to Ecstasy
Description: The London group’s opulent debut album channels baroque pop and prog of yore, yet for all its high drama, the results sometimes sound too carefully plotted and curiously professional.

Title: init ding + _snd
Description: On two LPs from the mid 1990s, members of Oval and Mouse on Mars ask what lies beyond music’s borders. Their sonic abstractions are as bewitching as the most tightly composed song.

Title: The Room
Description: The Brazilian guitarist and L.A. saxophonist’s collaboration is charming and intimate. The pair coils themselves around these songs, prioritizing rhythmic complexity and sheer prettiness over far-out exploration.

Title: The Interrogator
Description: The latest album from the Washington, D.C.-based band led by songwriter and critic Elizabeth Nelson is smart, sturdy, reference-rich rock.

Title: Dreamfear / Boy Sent From Above EP
Description: The UK producer’s first EP for XL is a throwback to the early days of rave that folds together breakbeat hardcore, hip-house, techno, electro, and freestyle. After all these years, Burial’s still got the touch.

Title: King Perry
Description: On what is billed as his final studio album, the late reggae legend is treated as an afterthought, buried in the mix beneath an incongruous blend of electronic styles.

Title: Spiel
Description: The New Zealand band’s debut is heavy but nimble, with the tight interplay of an old-fashioned indie rock power trio.

Title: Compassion
Description: The jazz trio’s follow-up to 2021’s Uneasy is irresistibly listenable, an immersive 66 minutes that exhales a particular aesthetic history even as it pulls on the pain and anxiety of our present.

Title: Hiyo
Description: The North Carolina band once sounded tethered to the past. Now, more than 20 years into its career, it trades retro Americana for more expansive cinematic atmospheres.

Title: Blue Raspberry
Description: The Nashville singer-songwriter’s second album is a deft and subtly surprising inquiry into romantic illusion.

Title: Live at the Liquid Room, Tokyo
Description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit a groundbreaking 1996 mix from Detroit techno icon Jeff Mills, a brazen and electric performance that enshrined his reputation as the most ambitious DJ in the world.

Title: People Who Aren’t There Anymore
Description: The Baltimore band’s latest is another emotional tour de force that tests the limits of their long-running sound.

Title: The Ceremony
Description: On his fourth studio album, the Louisiana rapper chills out, finds some inner peace, and sticks to the middle of the road.

Title: Cloudward
Description: Performing with her jazz ensemble, the New York guitarist makes music that hangs in the balance between composition and improvisation, structure and dissolution.

Title: Lovegaze
Description: With regal harp strings, droning synths, and kinked guitar lines, the Los Angeles multi-instrumentalist’s full-length debut establishes her as a loose but imaginative composer.

Title: What Do We Do Now
Description: Like its 2018 predecessor, J Mascis’ fourth solo album plays a little like Dinosaur Jr. Jr., another softer guitar-focused outing with acoustic touches and electric sparks.

Title: We Blame Chicago
Description: Numero Group’s deluxe 5xLP box set looks back on a cult band that forged an unconventional blend of math rock and post-hardcore in the early 2000s.

Title: What an Enormous Room
Description: Having found unexpected happiness in her personal life, Mackenzie Scott approaches self-reflection with cautious optimism on her latest album, tentatively teasing the edges of her playful sound.

Title: LOS X NUTTY
Description: The Detroit siblings dial down the intensity of their underworld street sagas, but their latest mixtape is still packed with drama.

Title: Philip Glass Solo
Description: At 87, the legendary avant-garde composer revisits some of his most famous compositions with the air of a master craftsman looking back on his life’s work.

Title: #HEAVENSGATE
Description: After breakout beats for Kendrick and Earl, the New York producer flexes his range on a new mixtape stacked with lesser-known talent.

Title: Junk
Description: The lifelong Bohemian rubbed elbows with Salvador Dalí, Gertrude Stein, and the Rolling Stones. His 1985 avant-disco LP, featuring Lizzy Mercier Descloux and Don Cherry, finally gets reissued.

Title: The Legend of ABM
Description: The Chicago industrial rap duo tears into the horrors of contemporary America over dark, glitchy beats that convey an omnipresent sense of menace.

Title: Three Bells
Description: The garage rock auteur’s latest is a mid-career standout full of gunky riffs and tender love.

Title: Bathhouse Blues
Description: The Berlin-based musician reworks audio from vintage pornography into unrecognizable forms, queering the lineage of ambient music and subverting stereotypical representations of gay sex.

Title: All Is Yellow
Description: Hip-hop video entrepreneur Cole Bennett directs an inevitable, overstuffed album with a lot of big-name features and little curatorial vision.

Title: Temple IV
Description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit an overlooked 1995 record from the experimental New Zealand guitarist, a psychedelic invocation of drone, noise, and the spiritual beyond.

Title: The Boy and the Heron (Original Soundtrack)
Description: In the latest soundtrack from his long partnership with director Hayao Miyazaki, the composer pares down to a minimalist palette that reflects the film’s nostalgic mood.

Title: Great Doubt
Description: The Danish experimentalist turns toward singer-songwriter introspection, finding drama and yearning in melancholy, understated arrangements.

Title: Penalty of Leadership
Description: On the pair’s second collaborative album, the stakes of their street sagas intensify as the Detroit rapper contends with the aftermath of a traumatic car accident.

Title: Selected Jambient Works Vol. 1
Description: The ambient power trio condenses a hard drive’s worth of marathon jam sessions into a succinct hour of cosmic minimalism and wooly post-rock.

Title: Wall of Eyes
Description: Channeling jazz, kosmische, and prog, the Radiohead offshoot’s second album burrows deeper into their strangely enchanting appeal.

Title: EKKSTACY
Description: The 21-year-old singer-songwriter’s new album dilutes jangly reverb and pop-punk energy into a sound that’s chemically weather-treated for commercial appeal.

Title: The Breakdown
Description: Wielding the moody beats and unflinching honesty of drill music, the Brooklyn rapper takes an intimate look into the oft-unseen realities of sex work and trans survival.

Title: Keep It Goin Xav
Description: Xaviersobased comes for the stoner party-rap crown on a mixtape that’s improvisatory, totally zooted, and New York through and through.

Title: Melt the Honey
Description: The Toronto lo-fi rockers deliver indelible hooks with slacker nonchalance.

Title: Talking to the Wind
Description: On a short but charming four-song EP, the Los Angeles singer-songwriter expands on the laid-back R&B of her 2022 breakout album, finding new frames for easygoing songs about love’s ups and downs.

Title: Saviors
Description: Attempting to cement their title as a legacy rock act, Green Day absorb the kind of lazy regression they once rallied against.

Title: Film Noir
Description: Swervedriver’s Adam Franklin reintroduces his solo project’s backing band as an amorphous collective; their largely instrumental album pairs psychedelic instincts with cinematic aims.

Title: Magda
Description: After a run of conceptually focused projects, the Italian musician gives free rein to his atmospheric instincts on an album of immersive ambient techno.

Title: Sd-2
Description: The Canadian producer laces glow-worm synths and house beats with vocal snippets culled from indie-folk gems and Billboard hits.

Title: Head Over Heels
Description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit a 1983 masterpiece whose sumptuous sonics and ecstatic approach to songwriting brought post-punk into a mysterious world beyond words.

Title: 99th Dream
Description: A new reissue of the ill-fated shoegazers’ 1998 album reminds us that even as their fortunes were fading, they remained undeterred in their pursuit of psychedelic bliss.

Title: Little Rope
Description: Grief clarifies the air in Sleater-Kinney’s taut 11th album, which processes loss and societal turmoil and finds strength in chosen family.

Title: INSANO
Description: On his ninth studio album, the Man on the Moon has never sounded more checked out.

Title: My Story Got Stories
Description: The Detroit rapper broke out in 2021 with an unmistakably funky style and jokes for days. Now he has to do it again.

Title: American Dream
Description: The Atlanta star’s third solo album balances a new level of celebrity and the icy realism that’s long been his signature.

Title: Are You There God? It’s Me, @ EP
Description: The Baltimore/Philadelphia duo builds on the harmonious folk-pop of its debut with proggy synths, maze-like arrangements, and a newfound sense of mischief.

Title: Obsidian Wreath
Description: The Virginia band takes the drama of screamo and black metal to grandiose new heights.

Title: Big Sigh
Description: After the Britpop gestures and electronic touches of her last two albums, the UK singer-songwriter explores a more pared-back mode that highlights her incisive lyrics.

Title: Love Drug
Description: The gravel-voiced Nashville rapper’s writing is all tension with just enough release to ensure he doesn’t explode.

Title: Letter to Self
Description: On its debut album, the Dublin-based post-punk band channels rage into communal uplift.

Title: Desire
Description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit a wild slice of ’70s Dylan, an album whose air of magic and misdirection remains utterly unique in his catalog.

Title: Hudson River Wind Meditations
Description: A new reissue of Lou Reed’s final solo album spotlights a side of the New York icon that few ever got to see: a quiet ambient composer.

Title: Orquídeas
Description: With a lavish new album, the Colombian American singer serves up lush ballads about protecting your peace and sizzling reggaeton to disturb it.

Title: Palermo
Description: The Buffalo rapper sticks largely to hard-boiled genre conventions, while German beatmaker Wun Two leans toward the abstract and atmospheric.

Title: Fantasías Histéricas
Description: On a disorienting and adventurous new album, the Mexico City hardcore band raises hell in pursuit of a better world.

Title: Project T-Pain
Description: After circulating underground for five years, the rapper’s new project recaptures the magic of his late 2010s glory.

Title: Dog Days
Description: The Minnesota rapper’s blurry, distorted tracks conceal downhearted emotion, half-told stories, and irreverent humor.

Title: A Flor de Piel
Description: Using a canvas of cosmic synth arpeggios and hissing electronics, the Colombian artist treats folk music as a living entity imbued with liberatory potential.

Title: Slime Patrol 2
Description: On the follow-up to her 2020 debut, the Tunisian producer flips trap samples and lounge jazz into idiosyncratic, blissed-out footwork and club music.

Title: DJ E
Description: The Bolivian American artist formerly known as Elysia Crampton spins Andean music, digital effects, and overwhelming distortion into a binary-smashing collage with ecstatic overtones.

Title: In Parallel
Description: The Korean electronic duo’s music is a curious world of bright colors, aqueous burbles, and even one otherworldly pop song.

Title: Sail the Seven Seas
Description: Where the South Korean singer, songwriter, and producer’s deep house is laid-back and breezy, her rapping is quietly, coolly defiant.

Title: Tapetumlucidum<3
Description: On her debut full-length, the Hanoi conceptualist sings of youthful heartache over glitched-out, sub-rattling beats.

Title: Ambient 1: Music for Airports
Description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit a 1978 ambient masterpiece that helped launch the genre through its technological savvy and its soft heart.

Title: Echoes, Spaces, Lines
Description: In the 1980s, the legendary Bay Area composer self-released her first three albums of roving, curious synthesis. Restored and remixed by master engineer Marta Salogni, they’re collected in a new box set.

Title: Fabric Presents Sama’ Abdulhadi
Description: This set from the Palestinian techno DJ and producer is sleek and rolling, fueled by driving rhythms and punctuated by moments of emotional release.

Title: Hometown to Come
Description: On her latest album, the South Korean singer-songwriter pairs warm, impressionistic lyrics with her most ambitious arrangements yet.

Title: Acopia
Description: On its second album, the Australian group strips its melancholy electronic pop down to a whisper, nodding simultaneously to 1980s ennui and 2020s anxiety.

Title: fLuXkit Vancouver (its suite but sacred)
Description: In a Fluxus-inspired work for saxophone, drums, and string quartet, the New York-based musician strikes a boisterous balance between composition and free improv.

Title: Troper Sings Brion
Description: The Portland power-pop artist covers a set of previously unreleased Jon Brion recordings that showcases the producer/composer’s underrated songwriting chops.

Title: Czartificial Intelligence
Description: The long-running rap supergroup’s comic book-inspired boom-bap is formulaic fun.

Title: Exit Simulation
Description: The debut album from the South Carolina producer and singer is a delicate, nourishing statement of ambient, operatic R&B.

Title: Àlááfíà
Description: The moody debut album from the Chicago-born producer is a layered, lo-fi set that ripples with ambient terror.

Title: Infinite Hatch
Description: With tangled riffs and lyrics that read like fridge-magnet poetry, the Baton Rouge duo makes mischievous art punk with a gleefully absurdist spirit.

Title: Weavings 2
Description: Led by Nicolás Jaar and featuring Angel Bat Dawid, Aho Ssan, Oren Ambarchi, and more, this 2021 performance of collective improvisation is by turns brooding, ecstatic, and surreal.

Title: Welcome 2 Collegrove
Description: Seven years after the original, the two rappers deliver a sequel that is unstuck in time, dotted with the vestiges of two bygone eras but imbued with few of those eras’ charms.

Title: Waillee Waillee
Description: Self-released in 1978, this gorgeous set of ancient songs and instrumental abstractions predicted the shape of folk to come.

Title: MJ Lenderman
Description: Before the Asheville guitarist found his signature blend of deadpan humor and tight hooks, he cut his teeth on the more introspective songwriting highlighted on his newly reissued 2019 solo debut.

Title: Who’s a Good Boy
Description: Produced by Mo Troper, the full-length debut from Brenden Ramirez’s power pop project surges with quiet confidence and an open heart.

Title: crux
Description: Cameron Mesirow’s third album as Glasser is lightly fanciful yet deeply felt, using subtle flourishes to consider the meaning of death and what comes after.

Title: Influential
Description: The Bradford boys make a bid for commercial glory on their fourth album, but they’re better off staying unhinged than appealing to the mainstream.

Title: We Only Talk About Real Shit When We’re Fucked Up
Description: The Queens-raised rapper’s fourth album is an inconsistent letdown, swaying between soul-baring R&B, cookie-cutter flexes, and empty posturing.

Title: For Who the Bell Tolls For
Description: On his third solo album, the former Foxygen player indulges his mischievous instincts while mourning dead friends.

Title: Aprender a Ser
Description: On their third album, the Mexican dream-pop duo leans further into their soothing and immersive sound, taking a soft dive into the comfort of solitude.

Title: a.s.o.
Description: The debut from the downtempo trip-hop duo is how it’s done. Its nuanced production and smoky mood deliver a completely stylish result.

Title: Paradise EP
Description: The Indiana band supplies a sunny Midwestern take on nostalgic, shoegazey dream-pop.

Title: Playing With a Different Sex
Description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit the stunning 1981 debut from the English post-punk band, an archly subversive album with style just as sharp as its politics.

Title: The World Is a Ghetto: 50th Anniversary Collector’s Edition
Description: The new reissue of a landmark album of 1970s funk restores the Los Angeles group’s reputation as multi-cultural pop savants and unstoppable improvisers.

Title: THINK LATER
Description: The Calgary dancer and singer’s second album strikes a tough pose but offers mostly forgettable trap-pop ballads.

Title: Fastingen-92
Description: A new reissue of the Stockholm multi-instrumentalist’s 2020 album highlights his knack for making a studio sound like a lightly psychedelic, breezy early-evening DJ set.

Title: Revanchist
Description: The English producer’s full-length debut is full of cresting arpeggios and massive supersaws. It’s an ambitious ode to the ecstasy of trance music.

Title: Truth Be Told
Description: The Brooklyn rapper’s vivid storytelling and golden flow have inspired emcees for nearly 30 years. But his new album pales in the shadow of 2021’s momentous Doe or Die II.

Title: The Singing Places
Description: Forty years after the pastoral new age of From Gardens Where We Feel Secure, the UK composer once again fuses chamber folk with rural field recordings, conjuring a vivid sense of place.

Title: Trances
Description: At once familiar and disorienting, the Australian-born, Berlin-based artist’s new album challenges any fixed ideas of what “guitar music” can be.

Title: On the Turning Ground EP
Description: The jazz-folk group blends acoustic guitar and percussion with dub echo and washes of synth on a mellow, intricate EP inspired by the natural world and its Bristol, England hometown.

Title: Alcachofa (2023 Reissue)
Description: The minimal-techno icon celebrates the 20th anniversary of the breakthrough LP where he first established his otherworldly percussive sensibility.

Title: Heavy Vibrato
Description: The Detroit rapper tears into his creative partner’s thick beats like beef jerky, showcasing his fiercest raps yet.

Title: Pink Friday 2
Description: Thirteen years after her landmark album Pink Friday, the pop-rap superstar aims to conjure and build on that moment with an ambitious 22-song statement that is a very mixed bag.

Title: Cromo Rx
Description: The Puerto Rican quartet blends streamlined psych pop, atmospheric chillout, and yacht-rock disco on a concept album about lovelorn dream states.

Title: Every Picture Tells a Story
Description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit the album that made Rod Stewart a star, a rollicking and surprisingly grounded document of early ’70s folk-rock.

Title: Tokyo Riddim 1976-1985
Description: A new compilation surveys the period in Japan when Jamaican influences mixed with the opulent melodies and high-production gloss of city pop.

Title: Me Neither
Description: On an adventurous new album, the guitarist blends improvised performance with quixotic touches of found sound.

Title: Ahora Más Que Nunca
Description: The Montreal duo’s scorching second album unites acid techno, future jazz, and hip-hop in service of incisive political punk.

Title: Ahora
Description: On its third album, the Spanish quartet adds complexity to its hooky brand of indie pop, fleshing out its arrangements and digging into darker themes.

Title: When No Birds Sang
Description: On a collaborative release, the grindcore and shoegaze bands team up for the rare metal album whose greatest virtue is its delicacy.

Title: Liz & Lauren EP
Description: Teaming up with Pale Blue singer Elizabeth Wight, the Brooklyn producer explores love and heartbreak in moody tracks that pair back-room house grooves with bedroom introspection.

Title: Slice EP
Description: On its debut EP, the sax-and-drums duo forges a signature sound that proves anti-pop experimentation can be a real good time.

Title: Sexta dos Crias
Description: The Brazilian DJ-producer translates the livewire energy of his viral videos into an album of impish, wildly unpredictable baile funk.

Title: Jolie Laide
Description: Nina Nastasia’s new project with guitarist Jeff MacLeod is a lonesome, deliberate meditation on memory, freedom, and loss.

Title: Life After Neph
Description: On his latest tape, the Rochester rapper softens his most outlandish barbs. He’s still magnetic, but the sluggish beats sometimes interfere with his oddball flows.

Title: Grog
Description: Unified by its abundant lo-fi charm and with lyrics referencing the Butthole Surfers, Dexedrine, and Taco Bell, the squirrelly New York alt-country duo sounds more playfully idiosyncratic than ever.

Title: Music Is Victory Over Time
Description: Blending triumphant jams with the mind-bending repetition of minimalism, the instrumental outfit offers a leaderless, collective shout of defiance.

Title: Night Killaz Vol.1 EP
Description: On a fun but monotonous EP, the Detroit dance-music duo stops the clock at the party’s peak.

Title: Adagio Fishing
Description: For decades, the Mississippi septuagenarian has self-released idiosyncratic fusions of blues, bebop, zydeco, ambient, and modern composition. This reissue confirms him as a true American original.

Title: Confidence Freaks Me Out
Description: Multi-instrumentalists Ramin Rahni and Ariyan Basu formulate intricate art rock with unusual time signatures and impossible-to-predict textures.

Title: Riot!
Description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit a  2007 album that permanently altered the pop-punk landscape and marked the arrival of the ambitious and brilliant Hayley Williams.

Title: 50 Years of De-Evolution 1973–2023
Description: This new 50-song box set traces parallel paths through the futurist rockers’ rise, fall, and eventual reunion.

Title: i/o
Description: After two decades of tinkering, the art-rocker’s first album since 2002 arrives in an array of different mixes. Yet the songs are refreshingly uncomplicated, reconnecting with Gabriel’s pop instincts.

Title: Migration Magic
Description: On its charmingly homespun debut, the Montreal band plays slap-happy rock music that’s more about feeling the spirit than stressing over perfection.

Title: When the Roses Come Again
Description: The fingerstyle experimentalist’s new album bends guitar, mouth bow, field recordings, and electronic detritus into vast tapestries of pliant drone.

Title: Hypnotized
Description: The Chicago footwork producer dials into a captivating, stripped-back style that sets tightly wound rhythms against ominous open space.

Title: 41 World: Not the Album
Description: The Brooklyn drill stars show they’re the best the scene has to offer on a debut mixtape with some distracting extras.

Title: Mamouna (Deluxe)
Description: A new reissue of the Roxy Music frontman’s 1994 album fleshes out its opulent funk with a wealth of unreleased material that pulls back the curtain on his insular creative process.

Title: Santhosam
Description: On her full-length debut, the Tamil Swiss singer and rapper presents a lively and ambitious blend of R&B, rap, and Tamil folk.

Title: SAVED!
Description: After retiring the Lingua Ignota moniker, the transgressive diva takes a scholarly deep dive into the ecstatic and strangely melodious world of traditional Christian hymns and original devotionals.

Title: Diagnosis
Description: The Chicago musician celebrates idealism on an album of vivid, jubilant art pop that refuses to be pinned down.

Title: The Night Shift
Description: The San Francisco rapper and Dallas producer are still having a good time on their lush and laid-back fifth album together.

Title: To Be Eaten Alive
Description: Though often plodding and generic, the R&B singer’s third studio album contains vivid flashes of her best songwriting.

Title: Duo in Concert
Description: These are the only known recordings of the legendary improvising guitarist and the celebrated jazz drummer. Though wildly abstract, their playing also feels like a conversation between friends.

Title: Synthetic Bird Music
Description: Experimental label mappa editions’ elegiac collection of avian electronics is full of deliberately laid textures and out-there approaches to composition.

Title: Ode to Stone
Description: Inspired by the rolling dunes of a Danish national park, the Copenhagen-based musician’s spare, drifting album peeks at unfathomable vastness.

Title: Fun Boy Three
Description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit the debut album from a trio that split from the Specials to forge a mischievous and mysterious electro-pop sound haunted by the racist violence entrenched in British history.

Title: The Complete Budokan 1978
Description: The 1978 double-LP live set At Budokan gets a remixed, remastered release of its source recordings, becoming the next maligned Dylan album ripe for critical revision.

Title: Rockstar
Description: Dolly Parton’s star-powered, overly reverential, 30-song rock album aims straight down the middle.

Title: A Charlie Brown Thanksgiving (50th Anniversary Edition)
Description: A new reissue collects the entirety of the 1973 television score for the first time; it’s a lithe, funky counterpart to the wintry, wistful moods of A Charlie Brown Christmas.

Title: And the Wind (Live and Loose!)
Description: On this triumphant live album, the Asheville songwriter transforms his dreamlike narratives into something joyous, collective, and free.

Title: Rainbow Revisited
Description: The acclaimed South African pianist meets Los Angeles’ ambient-jazz ringleader for a session that shuttles between atmospheric studio experiments and gorgeously unadorned solo takes.

Title: A Grisaille Wedding
Description: The smoldering collaborative album between the experimental singer-producer and ambient duo casts overwhelming emotions into stark relief.

Title: New Blue Sun
Description: The rapper and now flautist’s debut solo album is an 87-minute devotional to new age, ambient jazz, and spiritual discovery. It’s beautiful, demanding, and among the most fascinating artistic left turns in recent memory.

Title: Back to Moon Beach EP
Description: On an album-length EP, Kurt Vile finds darker shades to his gold-hued worldview.

Title: Hearth Room
Description: The hyperactive New York sibling duo embraces genuine presence and warmth on its second album of the year. It feels like a radical reinvention.

Title: Jazz From Hell
Description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit the oddball rock maverick’s final studio album, a MIDI-powered vision of the uncanny and bizarre future of music.

Title: Quaranta
Description: With an uncharacteristically somber tone, the Detroit rapper's sixth album is his most introspective and confessional work to date.

Title: HeadSpace
Description: The New Jersey producer and Brooklyn rapper’s slanted, rhythmically intricate electronic rap album sounds beamed in from the future.

Title: Babyxsosa EP
Description: The Virginia rapper-singer is known for her boisterous rap concoctions, but her new album is a sparse showcase of moody, Auto-Tuned vocals that feel more like demos.

Title: Intiha
Description: Pairing songs rooted in classic Sufi poetry with electronic abstraction, the two experimentalists blur lines between cultures and eras in a moving tribute to the multiplicity of identity.

Title: Random Access Memories (Drumless Edition)
Description: A drum-free but otherwise identical new version of Random Access Memories brings the saga of Daft Punk’s 2013 album to a curious, unfulfilling end.

Title: Cat Power Sings Dylan: The 1966 Royal Albert Hall Concert
Description: No stranger to singing other people’s songs, Chan Marshall attempts her most ambitious cover project yet: an album-length recreation of a Dylan concert that changed the course of rock history.
The American photographer reflects on the past with a collection of warm, intimate piano compositions influenced by traditional folk and gospel.

Title: I was too young to hear silence
Description: The prolific saxophonist recorded this stark, searching album at 1:30 a.m. in an underground parking garage; it is both an exploration of negative space and an exorcism of ghosts.

Title: Hadsel
Description: The band’s sixth album is familiar and intimate, updated with touches of synth and drum machine but still rooted in melancholy brass and Zach Condon’s distinct baritone.

Title: Uchigawa Tankentai EP
Description: While the Japanese producer’s early music was grounded in footwork, he relegates rhythm to the margins on his latest EP, arranging his samples into wild abstractions and warped folk songs.

Title: Spiritual Cramp
Description: The Bay Area rock band refines its chaotic energy on its concise, catchy, and semi-ridiculous debut.

Title: Quarter Life Crisis
Description: Like Olivia Rodrigo if she were raised on P!nk, 26-year-old singer Arabella Latham writes shiny, uncynical pop songs full of sarcasm, screw-ups, and young-adult heartache.

Title: Overground
Description: On its first album in seven years, the Detroit punk band balances grid-like rigidity with the sense that everything is about to fall apart.

Title: Crueger EP
Description: The teenage newcomer’s latest EP is a maximalist maelstrom of frothy hi-hats and hazy synths. It contains flashes of brilliance, but sometimes falls back on cheap imitation.

Title: Integrated Tech Solutions
Description: The New York rapper’s tenth album showcases his turn from athletic feats on the mic to more expressive modes, backed by some of his best production yet.

Title: Autopoiética
Description: The endlessly adaptable Chilean star flexes her versatility across synthy bossa nova, breezy trip hop, pummeling dance-punk, and dirty perreo.

Title: Death Is Home
Description: On a gothic and stormy new album, the experimental producer and vocalist constructs alien landscapes whose unpredictable structures seek to tune us more deeply into ourselves.

Title: Lados B
Description: Recorded outdoors during the pandemic with bassist Anna Butterss and guitarist Jeff Parker, the Chicago percussionist’s sunny, vibey jazz record brings back a distinct era of rediscovery and anti-nostalgia.

Title: The Sign
Description: Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit the debut album by the positive-thinking Swedish pop group whose fusion of synth-pop and reggae became a preposterous international success.

Title: Up (25th Anniversary Edition)
Description: Undergoing personnel changes and toying with new technology, the band changed gears in 1998, adopting an atmospheric sound that left both longtime fans and recent converts scratching their heads.

Title: I<3UQTINVU
Description: The UK duo loosen their collars on their new remix compilation, pushing the songs on 2022’s I Love You Jennifer B to more mischievous, high-energy places.

Title: Heaven knows
Description: The debut album from the young pop figure transforms her jittery, emotional miniatures into songs that feel more extroverted, more joyful, and sometimes more complete.

Title: Empty Country II
Description: On his latest album, the former Cymbals Eat Guitars frontman takes an imagistic, detail-driven look at the dark corners of America.

Title: The Derivative Sounds Of... or... A Dog Always Returns to Its Vomit
Description: The Australian punk musician continues his prolific streak on a fun and occasionally melancholic tribute to mid-’60s garage-pop.

Title: Bolted
Description: On his first studio album since 2017, Matthew Barnes details the inner mechanics of loneliness and frailty, mapping them onto lurching rhythms and agonized, alienated cries.

Title: Return to Archive
Description: Drawing on samples of nature and science recordings, the experimental duo crafts a motley, riotous album from the Folkways Records archive.

Title: Suntub
Description: The Danish musician’s vibrant, uncanny new album gives alt-rock a hyperreal gleam.

Title: Aging
Description: The Broken Social Scene frontman confronts loss, survival, and addiction on a set of brooding dispatches from middle age.

Title: The Comeback Kid
Description: On her first album in a decade, the New York guitarist returns to her pyrotechnic displays of virtuosity. The pace is fast, the tone raw, the mood appropriately triumphant.

Title: Blanket
Description: The Brockhampton leader embraces a grungy, guitar-centric new sound on his first solo album since the dissolution of his rap collective.

Title: Sucker
Description: The new album from pop balladeer Jilian Medford unwinds the emotional pressure, leaning into high-adrenaline hooks and poignant moments of self-reflection.

Title: The Silver Cord
Description: The Australian psychonauts embark on a two-part mythological synth odyssey. It’s one of their wackiest and most uninhibited records to date.

Title: The Twits
Description: On its second album of 2023, the London trio looks to enliven its bookish, deadpan indie rock formula.

Title: Ultrabelleza
Description: The Andalusian singer’s debut brushes electronic beats and R&B melodies over a flamenco canvas. It is a masterful meditation on ancestral struggle that looks back to find a way forward.

Title: Memory Lane 2
Description: The Baltimore rapper helps the superproducer loosen up on their new collaborative album, a follow-up to 2021’s Memory Lane.

Title: Long Gradus
Description: In a minimalist piece presented in four different iterations—for strings, woodwinds, brass and organ, and choir and electronics—the Los Angeles composer strips her music down to its bones.

Title: LXXXVIII
Description: On his wily, restless new album as Actress, Darren Cunningham expands the canvas to make room for private jokes, stray thoughts, and cryptic musings.

Title: Hard Light
Description: On its first album in 30 years, the Boston shoegaze band looks back with tenderness.
